note_models.name: Cloze
Basic

fields:
Semi-batch Reactor - Where one {{c1::reagent}} is put in, and another is {{c2::fed continuously}}. The {{c3::concentration}} of product will {{c4::increase with time}} and thus is not {{c5::steady state}}.

Continuous stirred tank reactor or continuous distillation column - the process operates at a {{c6::fixed temperature}} and {{c6::pressure}}, with {{c7::feed}} going in at a {{c8::steady rate}} and {{c9::products}} being {{c10::taken out}} at a {{c11::matching rate}}.

Batch chemical reactor - {{c12::unsteady state}} - the {{c13::materials}} are {{c14::mixed together}} and {{c14::react}} (thus changing the {{c15::chemical composition}}) with {{c16::time}}. 

Boiling point of the mixture and the condensing temperature of the distillate also change with time.
Stoichiometric Equation, Coefficients and Ratios

Equation - Statment of the relative number of molecules of reactants and products that participate in the reaction. 

A valid stoichiometric equation must be balanced: the numebr of atoms of each atomic species must be the same on both sides of the equation, since atoms cacnnot be created nor destroyed in chemical reactions. 

Coefficient - The numbers that precede the symbols for each species are the stoichiometric coefficients of the species. 
Typically written without units in stoichiometric equations but when they are used in mass balances, they typically take the units (mol, kmol, lb-mole).

Ratio of two molecular species participating in a reacction is the ratio of their stoichiometric coefficients in the balanced reaction equation. 

Ratio can be used as a conversion factor to calculate the amount of a particular reactant/product that was consumed/produced, given a quantity of another reactant or product that participated in the reaction.
Excess Reactant and Limiting Reactant

A reactant is limiting if it is present in less than its stoichiometric proportion relative to every other reactnat. 

If all reactants are present in stoichiometric proportion than there is no limiting reactant (or all of the reactants are limiting).
Stoichiometric Requirement of A and Fractional Excess

Where \((n_A)_feed\) is the number of moles of excess reactant, A present in the feed to a reactor. 

\((n_A)_stoich\) is the stoichiometric requirement of A, or the amount needed to react completely with the limiting reactant. 

\((n_A)_feed-(n_A)_stoich\) is the amount by which the A in the feed exceeds the amount needed to react completely if the reaction goes to completion. 

\(Fractional Excess of A=((n_A)_feed-(n_A)_stoich)/((n_A)_stoich)\)

The percentage excess of A is 100 times the fractional excess of A.
Extent of Reaction

The reaction coordinate

The ratio of the number of molecules of a substance consumed or produced in a chemical reaction to its stoichiometric coefficient. 

DoF Analysis 

No. unknown labeled variables
+No. independent chemical reactions (one unknown extent of reaction for each)
-No. independent reactive species (one equation for each species in terms of extent of reaction)
-No. independent nonreactive species (one mass balance equation for each)
-No. process specificaitions (other euqations relating unknown variables)
Heat of Reaction
The enthalpy difference when stoichiometric quantities of reactants and products at a given temperature and pressure, react completely to form products at the same temperature and pressure.
Batch Reactors

Used for small scale operations, testing new products and manufacturing expensive products. 

Batch reactors are normally used for liquid phase reactions which require long processing times.

Has neither inflow nor outflow of reactants over time. (closed system).

Advantages
High conversions, obtained by leaving reactants over long time periods. 

Disadvantages
High labour costs per batch.
Variability of products between batches.
Elevated labour costs per batch.
Scale-up difficulties
Continuous Flow Reactors

Operate at steady state.

Continuous Stirred Tank Reactors (CSTR)

Plug Flow Reactors (PFR)

Packed-Bed Reactors (PBR)
Average Residence Time
The average time that a molecules stays within the reactor. The time a molecule enters the reactor until it goes out of it. Either the same unreacted molecule or as a product molecule.
Homogenous Reaction

Reaction taht involves a single phase. 

Heterogenous Reaction - Involves more than one phase. (multiple phase reaction).
Molecularity

Number of atoms, ions or molecules involved (colliding) in  a reaction step. 

Unimolecular, bimolecular and termolecular (reactions involving respectively one, two or three atoms (or molecules) intearacting or colliding in any one reaction steap.
Elementary Reaciton

One that involves a single step.

There are many reactions where the stoichiometric coefficients in the reaction are identical to the reaction orders, but the reactions are NOT elementary, owning to such things as reaction pathways involving intermediates and series reactions.

Reactions where the stoichiometric coefficients are identical to the reaciton orders in the rate law, are said to follow an elementary rate law. However, these reactions are not elementary reactions. 

The determination of whether a reaction is elementary or follows an elementary rate law occurs by means of experimental observations.
Active Intermediates

High-energy molecule that reacts virtually as fast as it is formed. 

Present in very small concentrations. 

Active intermediate A* can be formed by collision or interaction with other molecules.
Activation Energy

Molecules need enery to distort or stretch their bonds so that they break and now can form new bonds. 

Molecules need energy to overcome the steric and electyron repulsive forces as they come close together. 

If the reactants are free radicals that essentailly react immidiately on collision, there usually isn't an activation energy. 

Activation energy - energy barrier to energy transfer from kinetic energy to potential energy between reacting moleucles must be overcome. 

Activation energy is the minimum increase in potential energy that reactants must be provided in order to tranfrom reactants into products.
Irriversible Reaction
Descriptive term and implies that a reaction proceeds to completion to such a degree that the residual amounts of unchanged reactants are almost immesurably small.
Differential Balances

Relates instantaneous rates of change at a moment in time.

The balance equation for an unsteady-state system at an instant of time is a differential equation.

Ordinary first-order differential equation requires boundary conditions which must be specified. 

Dependent variable (M) and independent variable (t) 

Every differential equation for a transient system must be accompanied by its respective boundary conditions.
Integral Balances
Relates changes that occur over a finite time period.
